required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Which Physical Activity Influences Achilles Tendon Blood Flow the Most?
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Warming-up Activities on the Vascularisation of the Achilles Tendon: a Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: Previous studies have shown that a decreased blood flow is a risk factor in the occurrence of Achilles tendon (AT) injuries. Based on the current literature, no consensus was reached as to the most solid warming-up of the AT. Therefore, knowledge about activities which increase blood flow in the AT could be useful in the development of a solid warming-up programme for the AT. The aim of this investigation was to define the influence of different kinds of physical activity on the vascularisation of the AT in a healthy asymptomatic population. Subjects performed five activities in randomized order: running, static stretch, dynamic stretch, cycling and rope skipping. The vascularisation of the AT of the dominant limb was measured with the non-invasive oxygen-to-see (O2C) device. Blood flow was measured before, immediately after, five and ten minutes after activity to investigate the duration of the vascular response to activity.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Achilles tendon blood flow
primary_outcome.time_frame: 3 minutes before and immediately (0 minutes) after the physical activity to assess the change in blood flow due to the physical activity
primary_outcome.description: measured with the non-invasive O2C device

intervention.description: Subjects performed five activities: running, static stretch, dynamic stretch, cycling and rope skipping

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- no history of Achilles tendon complaints
- healthy and active adolescents
Exclusion Criteria:
- history of Achilles tendon pain or current complaints
- not healthy or not active population
- children
